data.title: Central Jersey’s 20 most famous celebrities
data.meta_description: What do Meryl Streep, Susan Sarandon & Halsey have in common? They hail from Central Jersey. They are among the region's 20 most famous celebrities.
data.meta_site_name: Courier News and Home News Tribune
data.text:
What is a celebrity? Someone who frequently appears in the tabloids and has millions of Twitter followers?

Perhaps celebrities live up to that name because they are celebrated, meaning they are followed by journalists and pundits, they appear frequently on television, and they have fans. In comparison, someone is famous because they are well known within a particular community for some achievement.

The following is a look at 20 of Central Jersey’s biggest living celebrities and most famous people, many of whom still live in Union, Middlesex, Somerset and Hunterdon counties. Some were raised in one or more of those four counties or were born in Central Jersey and grew up elsewhere in the state.

They are presented by county and then alphabetically by name. See a video above for a ranking of the most famous local celebs. A list of additional famous folks can be found below. Enjoy, argue and feel free to comment online.

Middlesex County

Jon Bon Jovi, Sayreville (born 1962, Perth Amboy): Founder of Rock and Roll Hall of Fame-nominated Bon Jovi with Middlesex County-raised bandmates Richie Sambora of Woodbridge, guitar; David Bryan of Edison, keyboards; and Tico Torres of the Colonia section of Woodbridge, drums. The millionaire rocker now lives in the Navesink section of Middletown. His JBJ Soul Kitchen in Red Bank helps feed the working poor and homeless.

David Copperfield, Metuchen (born there in 1956): Raised David Seth Kotkin, Cooperfield is the most commercially successful magician in history with a ticket gross of $4 billion and Top 20 celebrity earnings of $63 million, according to Forbes magazine. His television specials have won 21 Emmys and he has earned a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame, French knighthood and Living Legend status by the U.S. Library of Congress. He lives in Las Vegas.

Jesse Eisenberg, East Brunswick (born 1983, Queens, N.Y.): Oscar-nominated for his role as Facebook found Mark Zuckerberg in the 2010 film “The Social Network,” Eisenberg recently wrote and directed a television pilot based on his “Bream Gives Me Hiccups and Other Stories.” A sequel to his breakthrough 2009 film “Zombieland” is in the works, and he is expected to reprise his role as Lex Luthor in the “Justice League” franchise.

Janet Evanovich, South River (born there in 1943): Like the beloved title character of her 24 best-selling Stephanie Plum series of romantic adventure novels, Evanovich is from Central Jersey. The Rutgers-educated writer is a 2017 New Jersey Hall of Fame nominee. She lives in Florida.

Donald Fagen, South Brunswick (born 1948, Passaic): The co-founding keyboardist of the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Steely Dan rock act lives in Brooklyn, but he caught the rock ‘n’ roll bug while at South Brunswick High School in the mid-1960s, having earlier been a fan of the jazz music that influenced him and his recently deceased band mate, guitarist Walter Becker.

Laurie Hernandez, Old Bridge (born there in 2000): Old Bridge’s pride and joy not only won gold and silver medals in the 2016 Summer Olympics, the famous gymnast also won season 23 of “Dancing with the Stars.” She still lives in Old Bridge with her parents and often makes Central Jersey public appearances, sometimes in support of her best-selling autobiography, “I Got This: To Gold and Beyond.”

Tim Howard, North Brunswick (born 1979, New Brunswick): Goalie for the U.S. national soccer team and captain of the MLS Colorado Rapids, Howard also has played for the world-renowned Manchester United club in England. He has played in more international games than other U.S. goalie, but he also spends his time as an advocate for Tourette syndrome, a neurological disorder he has battled throughout his life.

Eric LeGrand, Avenel section of Woodbridge (born there in 1990): Like fellow famous New Jerseyan, the late Christopher Reeve, Eric LeGrand has done so much to raise awareness about paralysis and funds to help cure it. The beloved former Rutgers football player is an inspiration with his two motivational “Believe” books and his Believe Foundation. He still lives in Woodbridge.

Anna Quindlen, South Brunswick (born 1953, Philadelphia): Quindlen is a Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist and author of the semi-autobiographical 1994 novel, “One True Thing,” which was made into a film four years later that landed fellow Jersey Girl Meryl Streep one of her many Oscar nominations. She is a 2016 inductee of the New Jersey Hall of Fame and lives in New York City.

Susan Sarandon, Edison (born 1946, Queens, N.Y.): Oscar winner for 1995’s “Dead Man Walking,” Sarandon was inducted into the New Jersey Hall of Fame in 2010. In addition to acclaim for more than 100 film and television roles, including five Oscar nominations and seven Emmy nominations, the social and political activist was appointed UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador in 1999 and received the Action Against Hunger Humanitarian Award in 2006. The 1964 Edison High School graduate lives in New York.

Joe Theismann, South River (born 1949, New Brunswick): Along with Dallas Cowboys wide receiver Drew Pearson, Theismann is the biggest star to come out of South River High School’s esteemed football program. A 2011 inductee into the New Jersey Hall of Fame, the 1982 Super Bowl XVII champion with the Washington Redskins also has enjoyed a successful career in sports broadcasting. He lives in Virginia.

Karl-Anthony Towns, Piscataway (born 1995, Edison): The 2014 national Gatorade Athlete of the Year for his All-State basketball performance at St. Joseph High School in Metuchen, Towns spent one year at the University of Kentucky before he was the No. 1 draft pick in the 2015 NBA draft. Unanimously named NBA Rookie of the Year, he now is a superstar for the Minnesota Timberwolves and lives in Minneapolis.

Somerset County

Michael Ian Black, Hillsborough (born 1971, Chicago): This comic-actor has starred in “Ed,” “The State,” “Viva Variety” and “Another Period.” Black has a new show on the horizon that he created for TBS, titled “Moon Cruise.” The author of several memoirs and children’s books, he occasionally writes a column for the McSweeney’s literary site, titled “Michael Ian Black Is a Very Famous Celebrity.” He lives in Connecticut.

Laura Prepon, Watchung (born there in 1980): Prepon is the star of two hit television shows, FOX-TV’s “That ’70s Show” and Netflix’s “Orange Is the New Black.” She lives in New York with her fiancée, “Hell or High Water” star Ben Foster, with whom she is expecting her first child.

Meryl Streep, Bernardsville and Basking Ridge section of Bernards (born 1948, Summit): Nominated for the most Academy Awards at 20 and winner of three, Streep is one of the most acclaimed actors of all time and considered the greatest of her generation. But her first role was as Lousie Heller in “The Family Upstairs” at Oak Street School, then Bernards’ junior high. Soon after, her family moved to Bernardsville, where she graduated from Bernards High School in 1967. She lives in Connecticut.

Union County

Judy Blume, Plainfield and Scotch Plains (born 1938, Elizabeth): Author of such classic children’s books as “Tales of a Fourth Grade Nothing,” Blume was inducted in the New Jersey Hall of Fame in 2010, having sold more than 82 million books for teens and adults, including the best-selling “Wifey.” She lives in Florida.

Halsey, Clark (born 1994, Edison): Born Ashley Nicolette Frangipane, this Grammy-nominated alt-pop songstress recently performed a sold-out homecoming concert at Prudential Center in Newark in support of her first No. 1 album, “Hopeless Fountain Kingdom.” A Pop Warner cheerleader while growing up in Clark, Halsey lives in Los Angeles. She will perform Dec. 8 at Z-100’s Jingle Ball at New York City’s Madison Square Garden.

George Clinton, Plainfield (born 1941, North Carolina): The founder of the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame act Parliament-Funkadelic, the most sampled band in rap history. Living in Florida, Clinton has enjoyed a solo career since 1981, often performing with the P-Funk All-Stars, sometimes featuring original members of Parliament-Funkadelic. He can be seen Feb. 8 at Keswick Theatre, Glenside, Pennsylvania, and Feb. 13 at B.B. King's Blues Club & Grill in New York City.

Ray Liotta, Union (born 1955, Newark): Liotta is best known for playing the pivotal role of Henry Hill in Martin Scorsese’s 1990 gangster classic “Goodfellas,” considered one of the 100 best American films of all time by the American Film Institute. In the mid-’90s, Liotta returned to his home state to shoot scenes in Clinton for the 1997 action film “Turbulence.” He now stars with Jennifer Lopez in the NBC-TV cop drama "Shades of Blue."

Jay Williams, Plainfield (born there in 1981): A nationally recognized All-State star of the esteemed St. Joseph's basketball team, Williams played college ball at Duke and was a two-time consensus All-American, setting several still-standing NCAA records on the way to a national championship in 2001 and Player of the Year award in 2002. Drafted in the first round of the 2002 NBA draft as the No. 2 overall pick by the Chicago Bulls, Williams now enjoys a broadcasting career as a college analyst. He was inducted into the College Basketball Hall of Fame this year.

More famous locals

Carlo Alban, Sayreville (born 1979, Ecuador): Versatile actor who has starred in everything from “Sesame Street” to “Prison Break”

John Amos, Tewksbury (1939, Newark): Star of “Roots” and “Good Times”

Billy Ard, Watchung (1959, Orange): NFL offensive lineman for New York Giants (whom he helped win a Super Bowl) and Green Bay Packers

Melissa Bacelar, Piscataway (1979): Scream queen and adult model

Michael Barkann, East Brunswick (1960, Jersey City): Host, anchor and reporter for NBC Sports Philadelphia and co-host of the "Mike and Ike" show on 94 WIP on weekday mornings

Rick Barry, Roselle Park (1944, Elizabeth): Eight-time NBA All-Star inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame in 1987

Brad Benson, Hillsborough (1955, Altoona, Pa.): Super Bowl-winning New York Giants offensive lineman and former owner of Brad Benson Auto Group in South Brunswick

David Bryan, Edison (1962, Perth Amboy): Co-founding Bon Jovi keyboardist and Tony-winning composer of “Memphis” musical

J.C. Chandor, Basking Ridge section of Bernards (1973, Morristown): Director of acclaimed films “Margin Call,” “All Is Lost” and “A Most Violent Year”

Chris Cimino, East Brunswick (1967): Meteorologist of NBC-TV’s “Today in New York” and occasionally the “Today” show subbing for Al Roker

Joetta Clark-Diggs, Hillsborough (1962, East Orange): A four-time Olympic track star, a 2013 inductee into the New Jersey Hall of Fame and longtime mentor of local youth.

Monica Crowley, Warren (1968, Arizona): Author, foreign agent and former radio and television commentator

Pat DiNizio, Scotch Plains (1955): Singer-songwriter-guitarist of The Smithereens

Robbie E., Woodbridge (1983, Alpine): Professional wrestling champion

Hallie Kate Eisenberg, East Brunswick (1992): Child star and younger sister of Jessie Eisenberg

Greg Evigan, South Amboy (1953): Star of TV shows “B.J. and the Bear” and “My Two Dads”

Taissa Farmiga, Readington (1994): Actress whose career was launched with the 2011 film “Higher Ground,” directed by her older sister, Vera (see below)

Vera Farmiga, Readington (1973, Clifton): Oscar- and Emmy-nominated actress who got the acting bug while a junior in Hunterdon Central High School

Andrew Fastow, New Providence (1961, Washington, D.C.): Former Enron CFO convicted of defrauding shareholders of millions of dollars for which he served six years in federal prison

Steve Forbes, Bedminster (1947, Morristown): Editor-in-chief of Forbes business magazine and two-time Republican presidential candidate

Vida Guerra, Perth Amboy (1980, Havana, Cuba): Model and hip-hop video vixen

Alison Haislip, Tewksbury (1981): Actress and TV correspondent for “Attack of the Show!” and “The Voice”

Tobin Heath, Basking Ridge (1988): Two-time Olympic gold medalist and World Cup gold and silver medalist who plays for the U.S. women's soccer team

Jack Jacobs, Far Hills (1945, Brooklyn, N.Y.): Retired U.S. Army colonel and Medal of Honor recipient for actions in Vietnam War, now a military analyst for NBC News and MSNBC

Jax, East Brunswick (1996, Atlantic Beach, N.Y.): Third-place finalist on Season 14 of “American Idol” in 2015

Artie Lang, Union (1967, Livingston): Comic on “The Howard Stern Show” and “Mad TV”

Paul Le Mat, Rahway (1945): Golden Globe-winning star of “American Graffiti,” as well as “Melvin and Howard”

Lisa Marie, Piscataway (1968): Model-actress known for work with Robert Maplethorpe, Woody Allen and Tim Burton

Fred Mascherino, Union (1974, Coatesville, Pa.), Guitarist-vocalist of Taking Back Sunday

Andrew McCarthy, Bernardsville (1962, Westfield): Brat Pack star of “St. Elmo’s Fire” and “Pretty in Pink,” as well as Tony-winning play “Side Man,” now TV director and travel writer

Tom McCarthy (1966): Oscar-winning screenwriter of the 2015 Best Picture winner, “Spotlight,” which he also directed, and actor in HBO’s “The Wire”

Page McConnell, Basking Ridge (1963, Philadelphia): songwriter-keyboardist in the rock band Phish

Mary McCormack, Plainfield (1969): Graduate of Wardlaw-Hartridge School in Edison who starred in “West Wing” and “In Plain Sight”

Sydney McLaughlin, Dunellen (1999, New Brunswick): 2016 Olympian, now a sprinter and hurdler for the University of Kentucky

Joe Nolan, Westfield: Traffic reporter for iHeart Media and the PA announcer for the New York Jets and Rutgers Football

Brian O'Halloran, Old Bridge (1969, New York City): Actor in Kevin Smith's “View Askewniverse”

Shaun O'Hara, Hillsborough (1977, Chicago): Former offensive lineman for the Super Bow-winning New York Giants, as well as the Cleveland Browns

Heather O'Reilly, East Brunswick (1985): Three-time Olympic gold medalist and pro soccer player

Drew Pearson, South River (1951): Super Bowl-champion Dallas Cowboys wide receiver

Matt Pinfield, East Brunswick (1961): Celebrity DJ featured at KFOG, SiriusXM, MTV, VH1, WHTG, the Melody Bar and Rutgers’ WRSU

Randal Pinkett, Somerset section of Franklin (1971, Philadelphia): Rutgers’ first black Rhodes scholar in 1994 and winner of “The Apprentice” season four in 2005

Cameron Richardson, Old Bridge (1979, Baton Rouge): Actress-model featured in “Cover Me,” “Point Pleasant” and “Alvin and the Chipmunks”

Peter Sagal, Berkeley Heights (1965): National Public Radio host

Richie Sambora, Woodbridge (1959, Perth Amboy): Co-founding guitarist of Bon Jovi

Steve Schmidt, North Plainfield (1970): Republican strategist who has worked on the campaigns of President George W. Bush, California Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger and U.S. Sen. John McCain of Arizona

Brian Selznick, East Brunswick (1966): Caldecott Medal-winning author-illustrator of “The Invention of Hugo Cabret,” which was made into an Oscar-winning film by Martin Scorsese

Nancy Shevell, Edison (1959, New York City): Heiress inherited an even bigger spotlight when she married Paul McCartney in 2011

Tico Torres, Colonia section of Woodbridge (1953, New York): Co-founding Bon Jovi drummer

Greg Tyndale, East Brunswick (1972): Star of Z-100’s “Elvis Duran and the Morning Show” as Greg T the Frat Boy

Vitamin C, Old Bridge (1972): Spawned several solo hits at the turn of the millennium and, as Colleen Fitzpatrick, was member of Epic recording act Eve’s Plum throughout the ’90s

Frederica Von Stade, Somerville (1945), Opera and Broadway star with more than 60 recordings to her credit

Rich Vos, Plainfield (1957): Two-time “Last Comic Standing” finalist with six comedy albums and DVDs

Gerard Way, Summit (1977): Lead singer and lyricist of My Chemical Romance

Paul Wesley, Marlboro (1982, New Brunswick): Star of “The Vampire Diaries”

Jayson Williams, Alexandria (1968, South Carolina): Basketball star who pleaded guilty to assault in a 2002 accidental shooting at his Alexandria estate and served a 27-month sentence

Malinda Williams, Westfield (1975, Germany), Star of Showtime’s “Soul Food” and Tyler Perry’s “Daddy’s Little Girls”

Robert Wuhl, Union (1951): Actor, comedian and writer best known for creating the TV comedy “Arliss,” and playing reporter Alexander Knox in Tim Burton’s 1989 take on “Batman”

Staff Writer Bob Makin: 732-565-7319; bmakin@gannett.com
